text:
Hello, Do you know how to transfer a site from a developer account to a customer account?

Thank you

Hi <@U02QQF80D0D>

There might be more elegant solution that I don’t know. But I’d use CLI to fetch everything you need (CMS related) from your dev account to your local environment and then push it to the client’s account.
More on local development commands that might help

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/developer-reference/local-development-cli>

Content-wise, there is a content staging that might help

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/features/content-staging>

<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/website-pages/redesign-and-relaunch-your-site-with-content-staging?_ga=2.37845217.357767065.1639080036-1490283871.1609926409|https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/website-pages/redesign-and-relaunch-your-site-with-conten[…]?_ga=2.37845217.357767065.1639080036-1490283871.1609926409>
I try but i can’t create sandbox account in the customer account.

In addition to Gagan’s comment you can also control the default domain that’s used for files. Instructions can be found here:
<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/files/copy-and-update-the-url-of-files-uploaded-to-the-file-manager>

Thanks for the help guys.
Both of these methods are kinda crummy.  Most websites start in a staging environment and then are switched over to a live site when the DNS is connected.  USUALLY this would fix all of these linking problems.  Having to do this manually is a big waste of time.

When you choose to change that setting doesn’t matter unless someone manually copy and pasted file URLs. Both file URLs will still route to the same file so if you’ve already distributed links at the CDN URL instead of your main domain they won’t suddenly break.
If you use the <https://developers.HubSpot.com/en/docs/cms/building-blocks/module-theme-fields|file field> to pick your files it will use the default domain setting on your account.
